parent_scope: Subseries consists of a diverse collection of photographs depicting citizens and scenes of Toronto. Subseries includes photographs of events (e.g., Works Department annual banquets, Orange Day celebrations); memorials, tributes, and awards (e.g., the Cenotaph at City Hall, a memorial to returning soldiers, McIntyre Football Trophy, Toronto's Centennial tablets); portraits of prominent members of the community (e.g., Commissioner R.C. Harris, Mayors W.J. Stewart and Thomas Foster, members of the Board of Control, photographer Arthur S. Goss and family); and photographs of Toronto landscapes (e.g., Cherry Beach, Leslie Beach, Sunnyside Beach, Rotary Club Gardens, Riverdale Zoo, High Park), streetscapes (e.g., Yonge St., Castle Frank Rd., Broadview Ave., Don Roadway), and buildings (e.g., Old City Hall, Art Gallery of Toronto, Toronto General Hospital). Also included are a series of photographs of TTC property in the St. Clair and Runnymede Rd. district.

ca. 588 photonegatives : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images of buildings and equipment associated with waste management and the maintenance of clean streets during the first half of the twentieth century. 
Photographs provide views of the following waste management facilities: the Don Incinerator and Destructor, the Wellington St. Destructor, the Island Incinerator, the Symes Rd. Incinerator, Destructor, and Ash Building, the Willowdale dump, the Woodville dump, the Pendrith Ave. city dump, and the Keele St. city dump. Also pictured are vehicles and equipment used for collecting waste (e.g., horse-drawn and mechanized garbage collection vehicles, flushers, waste paper cabinets, auto eductors) and for cleaning and clearing streets (e.g., sprinkler trucks, snow removal equipment). 
Given the City's reliance on horse-powered street cleaning vehicles during much of the period covered by this subseries, there are numerous photographs of horses, horse shows, cattle markets, and stables (i.e., Lansdowne Ave. stables, Western stables, Northern stables, the old and new Eastern stables, Coxwell Ave. stables, Keele St. stables, Weston stables).  
Photographs are arranged chronologically by date.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of photographs of roads and bridges around Toronto. Arranged chronologically, photographs provide views of numerous bridges and underpasses not otherwise documented in individual subseries within Series 372. Photographs also record accidents (fire damage, railcar jumping the tracks) and instances of structural failure (washouts, collapse).
In addition to the focus on roads and bridges, there are a group of photographs of boats and docks, as well as images documenting cement and concrete testing.

394 photoprints : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
394 photonegatives : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
parent_title: Construction photographs of St. Clair Avenue E. viaduct
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of photographs documenting the construction of the St. Clair Viaduct located at St. Clair Ave. E. between Avoca Ave. and Inglewood Dr. Spanning the Vale of Avoca ravine, this structure replaced an older steel bridge that had been built in 1890. 
Arranged chronologically, photographs provide general, detail, and birds eye views of the progress of construction, including images of the excavation, timbering, footings, abutments, and concrete forms. Subseries also include images of the dismantling of the old steel bridge and the diversion of the creek running through the ravine. 
The following streets are referenced in this subseries: St. Clair Ave. E., Pleasant Blvd., Avoca Ave., Mount Pleasant Blvd., and Inglewood Dr.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of a miscellaneous group of images assembled by the archivist from photographs that did not readily fit into any existing category in Series 372.
Arranged chronologically, photographs in this subseries cover a diverse range of subjects, from architecture (bridges and buildings) and transportation (illegal parking, streetcars, and street cleaning) to public works (waste incineration, sewers, water distribution networks, and Works facilities) and police and fire services (stations and fire halls). There are numerous photographs of intersections located around the city, as well as views of stagnant ponds, fire damage, civic events.

394 photoprints : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
394 photonegatives : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
parent_title: Construction photographs of St. Clair Avenue E. viaduct
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of photographs documenting the construction of the St. Clair Viaduct located at St. Clair Ave. E. between Avoca Ave. and Inglewood Dr. Spanning the Vale of Avoca ravine, this structure replaced an older steel bridge that had been built in 1890. 
Arranged chronologically, photographs provide general, detail, and birds eye views of the progress of construction, including images of the excavation, timbering, footings, abutments, and concrete forms. Subseries also include images of the dismantling of the old steel bridge and the diversion of the creek running through the ravine. 
The following streets are referenced in this subseries: St. Clair Ave. E., Pleasant Blvd., Avoca Ave., Mount Pleasant Blvd., and Inglewood Dr.

parent_scope: Subseries consists of photographs documenting Toronto's water distrubution network during the first half of the twentieth century. Photographs in this subseries fall into two general categories: general views of facilities and detail views of specific components of the city's filtration plants, reservoirs, and pumping stations (e.g., pumps, filters, conduits, intake pipes, etc.). Subseries also features photographs of charts, plans, and mechanical drawings relating to water levels, water consumption, and water works facilities. Photographs in this subseries are arranged chronologically.

parent_title: Construction photographs of St. Clair Avenue E. viaduct
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of photographs documenting the construction of the St. Clair Viaduct located at St. Clair Ave. E. between Avoca Ave. and Inglewood Dr. Spanning the Vale of Avoca ravine, this structure replaced an older steel bridge that had been built in 1890. 
Arranged chronologically, photographs provide general, detail, and birds eye views of the progress of construction, including images of the excavation, timbering, footings, abutments, and concrete forms. Subseries also include images of the dismantling of the old steel bridge and the diversion of the creek running through the ravine. 
The following streets are referenced in this subseries: St. Clair Ave. E., Pleasant Blvd., Avoca Ave., Mount Pleasant Blvd., and Inglewood Dr.

parent_scope: Subseries consists of a diverse collection of photographs depicting citizens and scenes of Toronto. Subseries includes photographs of events (e.g., Works Department annual banquets, Orange Day celebrations); memorials, tributes, and awards (e.g., the Cenotaph at City Hall, a memorial to returning soldiers, McIntyre Football Trophy, Toronto's Centennial tablets); portraits of prominent members of the community (e.g., Commissioner R.C. Harris, Mayors W.J. Stewart and Thomas Foster, members of the Board of Control, photographer Arthur S. Goss and family); and photographs of Toronto landscapes (e.g., Cherry Beach, Leslie Beach, Sunnyside Beach, Rotary Club Gardens, Riverdale Zoo, High Park), streetscapes (e.g., Yonge St., Castle Frank Rd., Broadview Ave., Don Roadway), and buildings (e.g., Old City Hall, Art Gallery of Toronto, Toronto General Hospital). Also included are a series of photographs of TTC property in the St. Clair and Runnymede Rd. district.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images of buildings and equipment associated with waste management and the maintenance of clean streets during the first half of the twentieth century. 
Photographs provide views of the following waste management facilities: the Don Incinerator and Destructor, the Wellington St. Destructor, the Island Incinerator, the Symes Rd. Incinerator, Destructor, and Ash Building, the Willowdale dump, the Woodville dump, the Pendrith Ave. city dump, and the Keele St. city dump. Also pictured are vehicles and equipment used for collecting waste (e.g., horse-drawn and mechanized garbage collection vehicles, flushers, waste paper cabinets, auto eductors) and for cleaning and clearing streets (e.g., sprinkler trucks, snow removal equipment). 
Given the City's reliance on horse-powered street cleaning vehicles during much of the period covered by this subseries, there are numerous photographs of horses, horse shows, cattle markets, and stables (i.e., Lansdowne Ave. stables, Western stables, Northern stables, the old and new Eastern stables, Coxwell Ave. stables, Keele St. stables, Weston stables).  
Photographs are arranged chronologically by date.

parent_scope: Subseries consists of photographs of streets and intersections across Toronto. parent_scope:
Subseries consists of a miscellaneous group of images assembled by the archivist from photographs that did not readily fit into any existing category in Series 372.
Arranged chronologically, photographs in this subseries cover a diverse range of subjects, from architecture (bridges and buildings) and transportation (illegal parking, streetcars, and street cleaning) to public works (waste incineration, sewers, water distribution networks, and Works facilities) and police and fire services (stations and fire halls). There are numerous photographs of intersections located around the city, as well as views of stagnant ponds, fire damage, civic events.

parent_scope: Subseries consists of photographs documenting Toronto's water distrubution network during the first half of the twentieth century. Photographs in this subseries fall into two general categories: general views of facilities and detail views of specific components of the city's filtration plants, reservoirs, and pumping stations (e.g., pumps, filters, conduits, intake pipes, etc.). Subseries also features photographs of charts, plans, and mechanical drawings relating to water levels, water consumption, and water works facilities. Photographs in this subseries are arranged chronologically.

909 photonegatives : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images taken for the Department of Health by the Department of Works photographer. Arranged in chronological order, these photographs focus on issues of concern to the Health Department during the tenure of Medical Officer of Health Dr. Charles Hastings. Subjects addressed in the photographs include: food and milk control, housing conditions and overcrowding, sanitation (including sewage disposal, plumbing, and drainage), quarantine and communicable disease control, potable water and water treatment, infants' clinics and mothers' classes, the activities of visiting public health nurses, and health and dental clinics held in Toronto public schools.
Subseries also includes photographs of offices, laboratories, and equipment associated with the operation of the Department of Health, as well as copies of charts and diagrams illustrating various public health statistics for Toronto.

title: Don Section
condition: OPEN - No restrictions on these government records.
copyright: Copyright is in the public domain and permission for use is not required...more
parent_desc: 862 photographs : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images that document progress views, structural details, structural failures, and equipment associated with the construction of the Bloor Street Viaduct. Later known as the Prince Edward Viaduct, this structure spans the Don River and connects Bloor Street East with Danforth Avenue. 
Photographs in this subseries are organized into four general groups. The first group consists of images showing the surveying of the route (ca. 1912-1916), with an emphasis on Glen Road, Castle Frank Road, and Danforth Avenue. The second group (ca. 1915-1918) focuses on the construction of the Don Section from the beginning of construction in January 1915 to the opening in October 1918. The third group documents the construction of the Rosedale Section from 1915 to 1918, including the opening in October 1917. The fourth and final group shows the construction of the Bloor Section (ca. 1915-1921), including the opening in August 1919. 
Also included in this subseries are views of Glen Road and the Glen Road bridge, Howard Street, Dale Avenue, Parliament Street, the Sherbourne Street bridge, Rosedale Valley Road, Castle Frank Road, and the Don River.

154 photoprints : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
160 photonegatives : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of photographs documenting the construction of the St. Clair Reservoir, located at St. Clair Ave. W and Spadina Rd. The St. Clair Reservoir is one of ten ground-level reservoirs in Toronto. It acts as a storage container for water, providing stable water pressure and ensuring an adequate and constant water supply for the district it serves. Additionally, the exterior roof has been landscaped as a park (Sir Winston Churchill Park) for area residents. 
Arranged chronologically, photographs provide general, detail, and panoramic views of the construction. Several images document cracks in the basin and overhead tank foundations.

physical_desc: 1 architectural drawing : pencil and crayon on tracing paper, col. ; 32 x 43 cm
subject: PARKS (browse  records)
condition: OPEN - No restrictions on these government records.
copyright: Copyright is held by the City of Toronto....more
author_notes: The initials "S.T.J.F." are inscribed at bottom right of drawing.
physical_desc_notes: Drawing, originally mounted on 46 X 61 cm paper in scrapbook, has been detatched and filed within tissue paper inside container.
numbers: Formerly cited as: RG13, Series H, Volume 1, p. 17.
parent_desc: 235 architectural drawings on 115 sheets : 212 drawings in pencil or ink on 104 sheets of paper or tissue (95 hand col.), 11 drawings on 6 diazo prints (11 hand col.), 12 drawings on 5 blueprints (1 hand col.) ; 46 x 86 cm or smaller
parent_scope: File consists of architectural drawings that were once part of a large scrapbook prepared by the City Architect's Department and, later, the Department of Buildings to showcase various Parks and Works Department projects, most of which were completed in the 1920's and 1930's. Nearly all drawings were created for the Parks Deptartment, and at a key point in time when Parks Commissioner Charles Chambers rapidly developed the parklands and recreational sites throughout the City. File includes an array of drawings for structures at Exhibition Park, High Park, Riverdale Park, the beachfront parklands, and many other areas of the City. Drawings are made up of preliminary sketches, elevations, cross-sections and plans for the following types of structures: band shells, bathing stations, boathouses, booths and platforms, fieldhouses, gazebos, lavatories, park gates and entrances, parking stations, and shelters. A total of 104 sheets of drawings contain original pencil sketches, most of which are coloured with crayon or watercolour.

parent_scope: Subseries consists of photographs documenting Toronto's water distrubution network during the first half of the twentieth century. Photographs in this subseries fall into two general categories: general views of facilities and detail views of specific components of the city's filtration plants, reservoirs, and pumping stations (e.g., pumps, filters, conduits, intake pipes, etc.). Photographs in this subseries are arranged chronologically.

parent_scope: File consists of photographs of the demolition of a building located at the northwest corner of Front St East and Frederick St. Originally this building was the shops building used by the Toronto Street Railway Company, which it opened in 1882 as a carhouse and shops for the horse drawn cars. The property was acquired by the Toronto Railway Company in 1891 and it continued to be used to build and repair streetcars. The property was acquired by the Toronto Transportation Commission in 1921, however by that time the facility had become obsolete and the TTC vacated the building when Hillcrest opened in 1924.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images taken for the Department of Health by the Department of Works photographer. Arranged in chronological order, these photographs focus on issues of concern to the Health Department during the tenure of Medical Officer of Health Dr. Charles Hastings. Subjects addressed in the photographs include: food and milk control, housing conditions and overcrowding, sanitation (including sewage disposal, plumbing, and drainage), quarantine and communicable disease control, potable water and water treatment, infants' clinics and mothers' classes, the activities of visiting public health nurses, and health and dental clinics held in Toronto public schools.
Subseries also includes photographs of offices, laboratories, and equipment associated with the operation of the Department of Health, as well as copies of charts and diagrams illustrating various public health statistics for Toronto.

Subseries consists of a miscellaneous group of images assembled by the archivist from photographs that did not readily fit into any existing category in Series 372.
Arranged chronologically, photographs in this subseries cover a diverse range of subjects, from architecture (bridges and buildings) and transportation (illegal parking, streetcars, and street cleaning) to public works (waste incineration, sewers, water distribution networks, and Works facilities) and police and fire services (stations and fire halls). There are numerous photographs of intersections located around the city, as well as views of stagnant ponds, fire damage, civic events.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images that document progress views, structural details, structural failures, and equipment associated with the construction of the Bloor Street Viaduct. Later known as the Prince Edward Viaduct, this structure spans the Don River and connects Bloor Street East with Danforth Avenue. 
Photographs in this subseries are organized into four general groups. The first group consists of images showing the surveying of the route (ca. 1912-1916), with an emphasis on Glen Road, Castle Frank Road, and Danforth Avenue. The second group (ca. 1915-1918) focuses on the construction of the Don Section from the beginning of construction in January 1915 to the opening in October 1918. The third group documents the construction of the Rosedale Section from 1915 to 1918, including the opening in October 1917. The fourth and final group shows the construction of the Bloor Section (ca. 1915-1921), including the opening in August 1919. 
Also included in this subseries are views of Glen Road and the Glen Road bridge, Howard Street, Dale Avenue, Parliament Street, the Sherbourne Street bridge, Rosedale Valley Road, Castle Frank Road, and the Don River.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images detailing the construction of the elevated railway viaduct along Toronto's downtown waterfront. The viaduct was designed to eliminate the railway grade crossing for major roads and a new Union Station for passenger traffic. The City, Toronto Harbour Commissioners, Grand Trunk Railway and Canadian Pacific Railway had their final design proposal approved by the Board of Railway Commissioners on July 1913. While the focus of the photographs is the road underpasses, they also document the extensive changes in railway infrastructure. Union Station, the architectural centrepiece for this engineering work, was also photographed extensively during construction. 
In addition, these images capture the transformation of the waterfront that occurred at the same time. Many buildings, such as the old Toronto Electric Light Company steam powered generating station, were torn down to make way for the new elevated trackwork. Approximately 2.7 million cubic meters of earth was moved to increase the track's elevation, coming from borrow pits in Leaside and Scarborough. Also included in this project were underpasses on Eastern, Logan, Greenwood, Coxwell, and Woodbine to eliminate level crossings. Construction began June 1925 and was completed on January 1931.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images of buildings and equipment associated with waste management and the maintenance of clean streets during the first half of the twentieth century. 
Photographs provide views of the following waste management facilities: the Don Incinerator and Destructor, the Wellington St. Destructor, the Island Incinerator, the Symes Rd. Incinerator, Destructor, and Ash Building, the Willowdale dump, the Woodville dump, the Pendrith Ave. city dump, and the Keele St. city dump. Also pictured are vehicles and equipment used for collecting waste (e.g., horse-drawn and mechanized garbage collection vehicles, flushers, waste paper cabinets, auto eductors) and for cleaning and clearing streets (e.g., sprinkler trucks, snow removal equipment). 
Given the City's reliance on horse-powered street cleaning vehicles during much of the period covered by this subseries, there are numerous photographs of horses, horse shows, cattle markets, and stables (i.e., Lansdowne Ave. stables, Western stables, Northern stables, the old and new Eastern stables, Coxwell Ave. stables, Keele St. stables, Weston stables).  
Photographs are arranged chronologically by date.

physical_desc_notes: Drawing, originally mounted on 46 X 61 cm paper in scrapbook, has been detatched and filed within tissue paper inside container.
numbers: Formerly cited as: RG13, Series H, Volume 1, p. 46.
parent_desc: 235 architectural drawings on 115 sheets : 212 drawings in pencil or ink on 104 sheets of paper or tissue (95 hand col.), 11 drawings on 6 diazo prints (11 hand col.), 12 drawings on 5 blueprints (1 hand col.) ; 46 x 86 cm or smaller
parent_scope: File consists of architectural drawings that were once part of a large scrapbook prepared by the City Architect's Department and, later, the Department of Buildings to showcase various Parks and Works Department projects, most of which were completed in the 1920's and 1930's. Nearly all drawings were created for the Parks Deptartment, and at a key point in time when Parks Commissioner Charles Chambers rapidly developed the parklands and recreational sites throughout the City. File includes an array of drawings for structures at Exhibition Park, High Park, Riverdale Park, the beachfront parklands, and many other areas of the City. Drawings are made up of preliminary sketches, elevations, cross-sections and plans for the following types of structures: band shells, bathing stations, boathouses, booths and platforms, fieldhouses, gazebos, lavatories, park gates and entrances, parking stations, and shelters. A total of 104 sheets of drawings contain original pencil sketches, most of which are coloured with crayon or watercolour.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images taken for the Department of Health by the Department of Works photographer. Arranged in chronological order, these photographs focus on issues of concern to the Health Department during the tenure of Medical Officer of Health Dr. Charles Hastings. Subjects addressed in the photographs include: food and milk control, housing conditions and overcrowding, sanitation (including sewage disposal, plumbing, and drainage), quarantine and communicable disease control, potable water and water treatment, infants' clinics and mothers' classes, the activities of visiting public health nurses, and health and dental clinics held in Toronto public schools.
Subseries also includes photographs of offices, laboratories, and equipment associated with the operation of the Department of Health, as well as copies of charts and diagrams illustrating various public health statistics for Toronto.

Subseries consists of a miscellaneous group of images assembled by the archivist from photographs that did not readily fit into any existing category in Series 372.
Arranged chronologically, photographs in this subseries cover a diverse range of subjects, from architecture (bridges and buildings) and transportation (illegal parking, streetcars, and street cleaning) to public works (waste incineration, sewers, water distribution networks, and Works facilities) and police and fire services (stations and fire halls). There are numerous photographs of intersections located around the city, as well as views of stagnant ponds, fire damage, civic events.

parent_desc:
638 photoprints : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
533 photonegatives : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images detailing the construction of the elevated railway viaduct along Toronto's downtown waterfront. The viaduct was designed to eliminate the railway grade crossing for major roads and a new Union Station for passenger traffic. The City, Toronto Harbour Commissioners, Grand Trunk Railway and Canadian Pacific Railway had their final design proposal approved by the Board of Railway Commissioners on July 1913. While the focus of the photographs is the road underpasses, they also document the extensive changes in railway infrastructure. Union Station, the architectural centrepiece for this engineering work, was also photographed extensively during construction. 
In addition, these images capture the transformation of the waterfront that occurred at the same time. Many buildings, such as the old Toronto Electric Light Company steam powered generating station, were torn down to make way for the new elevated trackwork. Approximately 2.7 million cubic meters of earth was moved to increase the track's elevation, coming from borrow pits in Leaside and Scarborough. Also included in this project were underpasses on Eastern, Logan, Greenwood, Coxwell, and Woodbine to eliminate level crossings. Construction began June 1925 and was completed on January 1931.

parent_title: Construction photographs of St. Clair Avenue W.  bridge at Wells Hill
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of photographs documenting the construction of the St. Clair bridge (also known as the Wells Hill bridge). This structure, located on a stretch of St. Clair Ave. W. between Wells Hill Ave. and Spadina Rd., was built as part of the construction of the St. Clair line of the Toronto Civic Railways. It replaced a fill project that had been swept away by landslide in 1912. During construction of the bridge, a temporary wooden trestle bridge was erected to allow for the opening of the car line.
Arranged chronologically, photographs provide general and detail views of the progress of construction, including images of the temporary trestle bridge and the new bridge.

parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images taken for the Department of Health by the Department of Works photographer. Arranged in chronological order, these photographs focus on issues of concern to the Health Department during the tenure of Medical Officer of Health Dr. Charles Hastings. Subjects addressed in the photographs include: food and milk control, housing conditions and overcrowding, sanitation (including sewage disposal, plumbing, and drainage), quarantine and communicable disease control, potable water and water treatment, infants' clinics and mothers' classes, the activities of visiting public health nurses, and health and dental clinics held in Toronto public schools.
Subseries also includes photographs of offices, laboratories, and equipment associated with the operation of the Department of Health, as well as copies of charts and diagrams illustrating various public health statistics for Toronto.

parent_scope: Subseries consists of photographs documenting Toronto's water distrubution network during the first half of the twentieth century. Photographs in this subseries fall into two general categories: general views of facilities and detail views of specific components of the city's filtration plants, reservoirs, and pumping stations (e.g., pumps, filters, conduits, intake pipes, etc.). Subseries also features photographs of charts, plans, and mechanical drawings relating to water levels, water consumption, and water works facilities. Photographs in this subseries are arranged chronologically.

parent_scope: Subseries consists of a diverse collection of photographs depicting citizens and scenes of Toronto. Subseries includes photographs of events (e.g., Works Department annual banquets, Orange Day celebrations); memorials, tributes, and awards (e.g., the Cenotaph at City Hall, a memorial to returning soldiers, McIntyre Football Trophy, Toronto's Centennial tablets); portraits of prominent members of the community (e.g., Commissioner R.C. Harris, Mayors W.J. Stewart and Thomas Foster, members of the Board of Control, photographer Arthur S. Goss and family); and photographs of Toronto landscapes (e.g., Cherry Beach, Leslie Beach, Sunnyside Beach, Rotary Club Gardens, Riverdale Zoo, High Park), streetscapes (e.g., Yonge St., Castle Frank Rd., Broadview Ave., Don Roadway), and buildings (e.g., Old City Hall, Art Gallery of Toronto, Toronto General Hospital). Also included are a series of photographs of TTC property in the St. Clair and Runnymede Rd. district.

909 photonegatives : b&w; ; 13 x 18 cm and smaller
parent_scope:
Subseries consists of images taken for the Department of Health by the Department of Works photographer. Arranged in chronological order, these photographs focus on issues of concern to the Health Department during the tenure of Medical Officer of Health Dr. Charles Hastings. Subjects addressed in the photographs include: food and milk control, housing conditions and overcrowding, sanitation (including sewage disposal, plumbing, and drainage), quarantine and communicable disease control, potable water and water treatment, infants' clinics and mothers' classes, the activities of visiting public health nurses, and health and dental clinics held in Toronto public schools.
Subseries also includes photographs of offices, laboratories, and equipment associated with the operation of the Department of Health, as well as copies of charts and diagrams illustrating various public health statistics for Toronto.
